Message.Issue: Change 'FoodRelated.CombinedFoodList' to be read-only by removing the property setter.
Consider a design where 'FoodRelated.CombinedFoodList' doesn't nest generic type 'IList<Tuple<string, float, float, string, bool>>'.

'Modification.WriteToObject(Label, TextBox, int)' creates an exception of type 'NullReferenceException', an exception type that is reserved by the runtime and should never be raised by managed code. If this exception instance might be thrown, use a different exception type.

Change 'PopupHandler.CreatePopup(string, Control, int, bool)' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Change 'Program.Application_ThreadException(object, ThreadExceptionEventArgs)' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Change 'Program.CurrentDomain_UnhandledException(object, UnhandledExceptionEventArgs)' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Rule.Name: Collection properties should be read only
Rule.Description: Properties that return collections should be read-only so that users cannot entirely replace the backing store. Users can still modify the contents of the collection by calling relevant methods on the collection. Note that the XmlSerializer class has special support for deserializing read-only collections. See the XmlSerializer overview for more information.
Rule.Resolution: Change {0} to be read-only by removing the property setter.

Rule.Name: Do not nest generic types in member signatures
Rule.Description: Avoid API that require users to instantiate a generic type with another generic type as type argument. The syntax gets too complex.
Rule.Resolution: Consider a design where {0} doesn't nest generic type {1}.

Rule.Name: Do not raise reserved exception types
Rule.Description: User code should not create and raise exceptions of certain types that are reserved by the runtime or which are of a too general exception type. Exception types that are too general include Exception, SystemException, and ApplicationException. Exception types that are reserved by the runtime include ThreadAbortException, OutOfMemoryException, ExecutionEngineException, and IndexOutOfRangeException.
Rule.Resolution: {0} creates an exception of type {1}, an exception type that is reserved by the runtime and should never be raised by managed code. If this exception instance might be thrown, use a different exception type.

Rule.Name: Specify MessageBoxOptions
Rule.Description: In order to run correctly on right-to-left systems, all calls to MessageBox.Show should use the overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions as an argument. Programs should detect whether they are running on a right-to-left system at run-time and pass the appropriate MessageBoxOptions value in order to display correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Change {0} to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.
